questions.text: A 64-year-old woman presents to the OG clinic with complaints of mass descending PV. On examination, you note that the external os lies at the level of the introitus. What is the degree of uterine prolapse?
questions.solution: In 2nd degree prolapse, the external os lies at the level of introitus.

questions.text: An infant was born at 32 weeks of gestation. He is being examined 12 weeks postnatally. What is the age of the child to be considered while undertaking developmental assessment?
questions.solution:
The corrected age (in weeks) to be assumed while undertaking developmental assessment is 4 weeks.

Corrected age (in weeks) = (Gestational age + postnatal age) - 40 weeks

Here, the gestational age is 32 weeks and postnatal age is 12 weeks. Therefore, with the above calculation, the corrected age is 4 weeks.

In babies born preterm, corrected age is used for their developmental assessment until 2 years of age.

questions.text: A 24-year old male stated that he had fallen with his thumb extended and presented with a painful, swollen thumb. The X-ray image is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The X-ray shows the avulsion fracture of the ulnar base of the proximal phalanx of the thumb, known as Gamekeeper’s fracture.

  • A gamekeeper thumb, also known as skier’s thumb is an injury to the ulnar collateral ligament (UCL) of the first metacarpophalangeal joint. The UCL may get ruptured or avulsed from its site of insertion on the base of the proximal phalanx.
  • Injury is usually caused by a fall on an outstretched hand with radial and palmar abduction.
  • Patients present with pain, swelling, and ecchymosis around the first metacarpophalangeal joint.
  • Diagnosis can be made on plain radiographs and/or anteroposterior stress radiographs.

Other options:

Option a: Bennet fracture: It is an intra-articular, two-part fracture of the base of the first metacarpal bone.

Option b: Rolando fracture is an intraarticular comminuted fracture of the base of the first metacarpal bone, with a ‘T’ or ‘Y’ configuration.

Option d: Epibasal fracture of thumb, also known as pseudo bennett’s fracture is a two-part fracture of the proximal first metacarpal bone.

Related Pearl: Important injuries of the hand

Gamekeeper's thumb: It is an injury of the thumb leading to avulsion, rupture or damage of the Ulnar collateral ligament. It is commonly seen in gamekeepers and also following a fall on an outstretched hand.

 
Mallet finger/baseball finger: It is a disruption to the extensor tendon over the DIP joint. It occurs when a collision with a hard object (e.g., a ball) forces it to flex more than its normal range of motion.
 

 

Jersey finger: It is an avulsion injury of the flexor digitorum profundus at the insertion of the base of the distal phalanx. The ring finger most commonly involved.

 

Trigger finger: A nodule on the flexor tendon prevents it to move along the A1 pulley. This causes the finger to be stuck in a flexed position.

 

Boxer's fracture: It is a break in the neck of the metacarpal. It is caused by striking an object with a closed fist, as seen in boxing. The little finger is the most commonly affected.

questions.text: A 26-year-old man was brought unconscious to the casualty ward following head injury. CT was normal. However, MRI showed multiple small hemorrhages, especially in the corpus callosum and the dorsolateral midbrain, with no midline shift. The probable cause is ________
questions.solution:
If a patient with head injury has a poor Glasgow Coma Score (GCS), normal findings on computed tomography (CT) scan, and evidence of hemorrhages in the corpus callosum or midbrain on magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan, the patient has a diffuse axonal injury.

Diffuse Axonal Injury

  • This is a form of primary brain injury seen in high-energy accidents.
  • It is caused by damage to axons throughout the brain due to rotational acceleration and then deceleration. Axons may be completely disrupted and then retract, forming axon balls.
  • Small hemorrhages can be seen in more severe cases, especially on MRI (investigation of choice). Hemorrhage is classically seen in the corpus callosum and the dorsolateral midbrain.
  • Prognosis is very poor.

Related Pearl: Diffuse Axonal Injury

Features of diffuse axonal injury
Mechanism Primarily a non-impact rotational acceleration-decceleration injury (this leads to deformation of the axons by stretching them)
Pathology

Changes in permeability of the axolemma

Axonal swelling

Intracellular calcium accumulation

Proteolysis

Collapse of the cytoskeleton
Histology

'Retraction balls or globes' - bulbous and clubbed axons. Seen earliest at 12-18 hours.
Immuno-histochemistry

Beta-amyloid precursor protein - considered to be the most reliable indicator of axon damage. Seen earliest at 2-3 hours. 

 

Retraction balls:

  • The force generated by violent shaking or rotational injury (as in a passenger ejected from the moving vehicle) can produce stretching of axons in cerebral white matter.
  • Microscopic examination does not show any axonal injuries up to 12 hrs after injury
  • After 12 hrs the axons first appear dilated then club shaped and finally appear as round balls known as retraction balls which indicates transected axons.
  • The number of retraction balls begins to decrease after 2-3 weeks after injury and cluster of microglial cells appear followed by astrocytosis and demyelination.

questions.text: The movement disorder shown below is most likely to result from a lesion in
questions.solution:
The movement disorder depicted in the above image is hemiballismus, and it is most commonly caused due to the partial lesion in the subthalamic nucleus. Other sites such as the putamen, caudate, globus pallidus, and parietal cortex are less commonly involved.

Hemiballismus is a violent choreiform movement with wild, flinging, large-amplitude movements affecting one side of the body. It mostly affects the proximal muscles and can be confined to one limb or affect both upper and lower limbs.

It is treated using dopamine antagonists.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with chest pain and breathlessness which is more on lying down and relieved on sitting upright. On examination, heart sounds are muffled. His chest X-ray is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features and X-ray appearance of the money bag heart is suggestive of pericardial effusion.

Plain PA chest X-ray shows an enlarged cardiac silhouette. There is effacement of the normal cardiac borders, development of a ‘flask’ or ‘water bottle’ cardiac configuration, and bilateral hilar overlay which are features of pericardial effusion. It is also known as money bag or leather bottle-shaped heart.

Pericardial effusions occur when excess fluid collects in the pericardial space (a normal pericardial sac contains approximately 30-50 mL of fluid).

Investigation of choice: Echocardiography.

Signs on plain radiograph include:

  • Globular enlargement of the cardiac shadow giving a water bottle configuration.
  • Lateral CXR may show a vertical opaque line (pericardial fluid) separating a vertical lucent line directly behind the sternum (paracardial fat) anteriorly from a similar lucent vertical lucent line (epicardial fat) posteriorly; this is known as the Oreo cookie sign.

Related Pearl: Radiological findings in some congenital heart defects

Boot shaped heart - Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF)

 

Egg on side appearance - Transposition of Great Arteries (TGA)

 

Snowman's heart appearance or Figure of 8 appearance - Supracardiac TAPVC

 

Box Shaped Heart - Ebstein's Anomaly

questions.text:
The given condition can occur due to the deficiency of:

1. Iron

2. Vitamin A

3. Riboflavin

4. Vitamin D

5. Vitamin E

6. Essential fatty acids.
questions.solution:
The given image shows multiple papules on elbows having a follicular distribution. This is known as phrynoderma or "toad-skin" which can occur due to the deficiency of vitamin A, B complex, riboflavin, vitamin C, vitamin E, and essential fatty acids. Options 2, 3, 5, and 6 are correct.

It manifests as groups of papules with a central keratotic plug. The commonest sites are elbows and knees. They are present around the follicles and give the skin a rough texture.

Treatment involves the correction of poor diet and administration of a multivitamin preparation containing vitamin A.

Other options

 Iron deficiency leads to anemia. Dermatological manifestations of iron deficiency are:

  • Brittle nails with longitudinal ridges- in moderate deficiency
  • Koilonychia- spoon-shaped nails in severe deficiency. It commonly affects third and fourth nails.
  • Atrophic tongue, glossodynia (pain in the tongue), aphthous and angular stomatitis.
  • Brittle, dry, and lustreless hair

Deficiency of vitamin D and calcium results in poor mineralization of bone leading to rickets. There may be fraying and widening of the metaphysis, prominent costochondral joints (rachitic rosary), craniotabes, bowing of the lower extremities, frontal bossing, scoliosis, fractures, and dental anomalies. The only cutaneous manifestation of vitamin D deficiency is alopecia.

questions.text: The investigation of choice for localizing the cause in a patient presenting with nasal discharge following a skateboarding accident, which has the following appearance on a tissue paper is:
questions.solution:
The image showing double target sign on tissue paper and the history is consistent with traumatic CSF rhinorrhea. HRCT is the investigation of choice for localizing the site of the leak in CSF rhinorrhea.

Though Beta 2-transferrin assay is the best laboratory test for identifying the presence of CSF in the sinonasal fluid it does not provide information regarding the site or laterality of the defect.

Related Pearl: Features of CSF rhinorrhea

  • Reservoir sign - In CSF rhinorrhea, the fluid which had collected in the sinuses, particularly sphenoid, empties into the nose.
  • Double target sign or Halo sign or Target sign - CSF is mixed with blood and collected on a piece of filter paper. It shows a central red spot (blood) and a peripheral lighter halo.
  • CSF can’t be sniffed back.
  • CSF doesn’t stiffen the handkerchief.

Note: Reservoir sign is also seen in acute mastoiditis/ coalescent mastoiditis where mastoid acts as a reservoir of pus and pus reappear in EAC immediately after cleaning.

questions.text: Which of the following is correct regarding the image given below:

choices.text: It is called Argyl Robertson pupil
The vision is normal in right eye
Seen in optic neuritis, the pupil can paradoxically dilate in the both eyes

questions.solution:
The image suggests Marcus Gunn pupil, which is seen in optic neuritis. The right eye is affected, while the left eye is normal.

  • The condition is named after the scientist, Marcus Gunn who belongs to Scotland.
  • Marcus Gunn pupil refers to the paradoxical response of the pupil to light in the presence of a relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD).
  • It is confirmed by the swinging-flashlight test.
  • The flashlight is swung to and fro and the pupillary response observed.
  • Normally, both pupils remain constricted.
  • In the presence of RAPD, when the flashlight is moved from the normal to the abnormal eye, both pupils dilate.
  • It is the earliest sign of optic nerve disease.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of necroptosis?

choices.text: Begins similar to the extrinsic pathway of apoptosis
Causes Recruitment of  RIP1 and RIP3 resulting in caspase activation
Terminal events include permeabilization of lysosomal membranes
Occurs during the formation of mammalian growth plate

questions.solution:
The genetic program that drives necroptosis does not result in caspase activation and hence, it is also sometimes referred to as caspase-independent programmed cell death.

Necroptosis:

This form of cell death is a hybrid that shares aspects of both necrosis and apoptosis.

It resembles necrosis morphologically and biochemically. Both are characterized by loss of ATP, swelling of the cell and organelles, generation of ROS, the release of lysosomal enzymes, and ultimately rupture of the plasma membrane.

It is triggered by genetically programmed signal transduction events that culminate in cell death.  In this respect, it resembles programmed cell death which is the hallmark of apoptosis. But in sharp contrast to apoptosis, it doesn't result in caspase activation.

  • Necroptosis begins similar to the extrinsic pathway of apoptosis. It starts with the ligation of TNFR1( Binding of TNF to TNFR1). Ligation of Fas can also trigger necroptosis.
  • Ligation of TNFR1 recruits RIP1 and R1P3 (receptor-associated kinases 1 and 3) into a multiprotein complex that also contains caspase 8.
  • Caspases are not activated and as in necrosis, the terminal events include permeabilization of lysosomal membranes, generation of ROS, damage to the mitochondria, and reduction of ATP levels.

Necroptosis is being recognized as an important death pathway both in physiologic and pathologic conditions. It occurs during the formation of the mammalian growth plate. It is also seen in steatohepatitis and pancreatitis.

Note: Necroptosis starts like apoptosis and ends like necrosis.

questions.text: A child aged 10 years presented with perianal pruritus which is worse in night. Routine stool examination didn't reveal parasite cysts or eggs. The scotch tape method is done to recover eggs which are non-bile stained. Identify the organism causing the infection.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the scotch tape method to collect perianal egg deposition by (Enterobius vermicularis) is  suggestive of infestation with Pinworm 

Characteristics of Pinworm egg:

  • It is colorless, non-bile stained.
  • It floats in the saturated salt solution.
  • The egg is planoconvex. Eggshell is double layered and relatively thick, though transparent.

Since pinworms are not released in feces, the diagnosis cannot be made by conventional fecal ova and parasite tests. NIH swab method and Scotch tape method are used for the collection of specimens.

Scotch tape method involves:

  1. Take a clear cellophane tape almost 4 cm long
  2. Hold it in such a way(or make a loop) so that sticky surface faces upwards or towards the perianal skin.
  3. Place the sticky surface of tap in the perianal area momentarily
  4. Place the sticky surface down on the glass slide. Examine under microscope.

 

Other eggs that can be collected by scotch tape method are Taenia solium, Taenia saginata and Schistosoma mansoni. Which are none of the options in question

Other eggs which are non-bile stained can be remembered as NEHA - Necator americanus, Enterobius vermicularis, Hymenolepsis nana, Ancylostoma duodenale.

questions.text: ‘X’ is an anti–epileptic drug given for treatment of partial/focal seizures and West syndrome. This is preferred in patients with a previous history of tuberous sclerosis. This drug has been given a black box warning as it can cause permanent visual loss. What is the mechanism of action of this drug?
questions.solution:
The anti–epileptic drug with severe black–box warning causing the permanent visual loss is Vigabatrin and it acts by irreversibly blocking the GABA transaminase to increase GABA action. It is used in the treatment of focal seizures and infantile spasms. 

Vigabatrin causes an increase in retinal thickness and directly damages the central retina. The other side effects of the drug include:

  • Dizziness
  • Tremors
  • Weight gain
  • Memory disturbances
  • myalgia

The other anti-epileptic drugs with visual effects include the following:

S.NO NAME OF THE DRUG MECHANISM OF ACTION NOTES
1.       Topiramate Blocks the sodium channel to increase GABA action Can cause angle closure glaucoma but no black box warning issued. Used in migraine prophylaxis
2.       Phenytoin Zero order kinetics and is a Na+ channel blocker

Diplopia.

DOC for recurrent seizure prophylaxis
3.       Gabapentin Clearly not studied

Macular oedema

used in post – herpetic pain

The drug of choice for infantile spasms is ACTH.

The drug of choice for infantile spasms in tuberous sclerosis is vigabatrin.

Infantile spasm (IS) is a convulsive disease characterized by brief, symmetric axial muscle contraction (neck, trunk, and/or extremities).Their occurrence is almost entirely limited to infancy (the first year of life) and they are refractory to conventional anticonvulsant drugs.

West’s syndrome refers to the classic triad of infantile spasms, characteristic interictal EEG showing hypsarrhythmia, and neurodevelopmental regression. 

ISs are resistant to most of the conventional antiepileptic drugs. Only ACTH, corticosteroids, and vigabatrin have conclusively demonstrated effectiveness.

questions.text: Which among the following acts via tyrosine kinase signalling?
questions.solution:
Somatomedin C (Insulin-like growth factor - 1) acts via tyrosine kinase signalling

All of the hormones below use tyrosine kinase signalling:

  • Fibroblast growth factor
  • Growth hormone
  • Insulin
  • Insulin-like growth factor – 1 (also called Somatomedin C)
  • Leptin
  • Prolactin
  • Vascular endothelial growth factor
  • Hepatocyte growth factor

Other Options:

  • Somatostatin acts via the cAMP second messenger system
  • Oxytocin and GHRH (Growth Hormone Releasing Hormone) act via Phospholipase C second messenger system.

Related Pearl: Classification of Hormones by Mechanism of Action

A) Hormones that bind to intracellular receptors

  • Cytoplasmic receptors
    • Steroids such as glucocorticoids, mineralocorticoids and androgens
  • Nuclear receptors
    • Thyroid hormones
    • Vitamins A and D

B) Hormones that bind to cell surface receptors

  • GPCR - G protein-coupled receptors
    • Gs - stimulation of the 2nd messenger cAMP
      • Examples: ACTH, CRH, TSH, LH, FSH hCG, Catecholamines (β receptors), Vasopressin (V2 receptors), Secretin, Somatostatin, and Glucagon.
    • Gi - inhibition of the 2nd messenger cAMP
      • Examples: Catecholamines (ɑ2 receptors), Acetylcholine (M2, M4), Somatostatin
    • Gq - The 2nd messenger is Phospholipase C (IP3 DAG Ca2+)
      • Examples: Parathyroid hormone, GnRH - Gonadotropin-releasing hormone, GHRH - Growth hormone releasing hormone, TRH, Catecholamines (ɑ1 receptors), Vasopressin (V1 receptor), Gastrin, Cholecystokinin and Oxytocin.
    • cGMP as the 2nd messenger
      • Examples: Atrial natriuretic factor, Nitric oxide
  • Tyrosine kinase receptors such as those that employ Janus kinase (JAK-STAT pathway) or MAP kinase pathway
    • Growth hormone, Growth factors (GFs) - eg: IGF, VEGF, FGF, PDGF etc, Erythropoietin, Insulin and Prolactin.

Note: Even though the cytoplasmic receptors are present in the cytoplasm, once the hormone-receptor complex is formed it moves to the nucleus for its actions.

questions.text: During DNA replication, DNA primase synthesises ______________
questions.solution:
DNA primase produces RNA primers during replication of DNA. These primers serve as scaffolds to which deoxyribonucleotides are added. The RNA in the primers is later replaced by DNA.

Okazaki fragments are lagging strands built on RNA primers by DNA polymerase δ.

Leading strands are synthesized by DNA polymerase ε.
